body.p: This document is targeted at developers, that are persons who want to contribute to the Community Z Tools project.

section.title: General remarks
section.p:
When you want to contribute, it is best to start from the sources from CVS. See the
documentation about CVS on sourceforge
for more information about how to access the CZT repository.

section.title: Starting a new subproject
section.p: Each subproject of CZT is located in its own subdirectory. To start a new subproject, say Foo, add a new directory foo into the root of the CVS tree. The structure within the new directory, should be as follows:

ul.li: README.txt --- the README file containing information about the subproject (prerequisites, how to build it, how to run it, etc.)
build --- this is a temporary build directory
doc --- this is the directory where the documentation lives
examples --- this is the directory where examples live
src --- this is the directory where the source code live
tests --- this is the directory where the tests live

section.title: Writing an ant build file
section.p: Ant build files are called build.xml and should use the following target names:

ul.li: install --- build the jar files and copy it into the CVSROOT/lib directory
test --- compile and run the tests

section.p: Properties that may be set by the user should be set in czt.properties, which is located in the root of the CVS tree, and read via <property file="../czt.properties"/>. Build files must not rely on environmental variables to work properly.

section.title: Java style guidelines
section.p: When contributing Java code, please follow the Java Programming Style Guidelines from Geotechnical Software Services.
